Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Incentive Spirometry in Bariatric Surgery Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery from May 1, 2015, to June 30, 2016, were randomised

Participants.evidence: This randomised noninferiority clinical trial was conducted at a single-center tertiary referral teaching hospital. Patients undergoing bariatric surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either postoperative IS (control group) or clinical observation without IS (test group)

Objective.evidence: The effectiveness of postoperative incentive spirometry (IS) remains uncertain.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the frequency of hypoxemia, defined as an arterial oxygen saturation (Sa o 2) level of less than 92% without supplementation at 6, 12, and 24 postoperative hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 224 patients were randomised, with 112 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was based on the evaluable population.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant differences in postoperative hypoxemia were observed between the control and test groups at 6 (11.9% vs 10.4%; P = .72), 12 (5.4% vs 8.2%; P = .40), or 24 (3.7% vs 4.6%; P = .73) hours.
